content:
Probably not a big deal, but the test cases aren't great for Reverse mode right now.

I got 100% on the tests with the below (admittedly stupid) code, but then failed 2 validators. For reverse mode, it's good to make sure you have enough tests that silly "solutions" like this don't pass them all.

require 'prime'
n = gets.to_i
a, b, c="No one can eat the snack", "All three can eat the snack", "Johnny and Bobby can eat the snack"
if n != 3 && n.prime?
  puts a
elsif n%3 > 0 && n.even?
  puts c
else 
  puts b
end

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: the puzzle is quite easy but maybe good for debutant!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: updated version with clear documentation

I've updated the altered version back to the original version as best as I can remember it. The author can update or revert my changes if necessary.

The following is both my updated version of the original and the assumed changes from another user:

Johnny and Bobby are both hungry for a small snack after their soccer practice at school. They have a snack that contains [[n]] number of chips, but they will only eat the snack if both of them get the same amount of chips each. However, before they eat the snack, Dobby also came from basketball practice and also wants to eat the snack, and they will only eat the snack if all three of them have the same amount of chips. Help Johnny, Bobby, and Dobby figure out how many people can eat the snack, as Dobby will just go home if only 2 people can eat the snack.

<<Line 1:>> An integer [[n]] representing the number of chips.

<<Line 1:>> A string depending on the following condition:
â€¢ If all three can eat the snack: {{All three can eat the snack}}
â€¢ If only Johnny and Bobby can eat the snack: {{Johnny and Bobby can eat the snack}}
â€¢ If none can eat the snack {{No one can eat the snack}}

0 < [[n]] < 1,000

=========================

Dans une vieille maison, il y a X piÃ¨ces, et chaque piÃ¨ce possÃ¨de Y fenÃªtres.
Mais attention : certaines piÃ¨ces sont condamnÃ©es et nâ€™ont aucune fenÃªtre !
On te donne X (nombre total de piÃ¨ces) et Y (nombre de fenÃªtres par piÃ¨ce normale).
Calcule le nombre total de fenÃªtres dans la maison.

Input description
Ligne 1 : Deux entiers sÃ©parÃ©s par un espace X Y

X : nombre de piÃ¨ces
Y : nombre de fenÃªtres par piÃ¨ce normale

Une ligne : le nombre total de fenÃªtres dans la maison.

1 â‰¤ X â‰¤ 100
0 â‰¤ Y â‰¤ 50
Why you said you must put 2 integer numbers as input  when you use 1 in example?
Did the puzzle just change completely?

Please change the first sentence from "Johnny and Bobby want are hungry for a small snack after their soccer practice at school." to one of:
â€¢ "Johnny and Bobby both want a small snack after their soccer practice at school."
â€¢ "Johnny and Bobby are hungry for a small snack after their soccer practice at school."
(It's also called football, not soccer ðŸ˜‰)

I'd suggest changing: "They have a snack that contains some number of chips," to "They have a snack that contains [[n]] number of chips,"

Also may be helpful to use the << >> tag to highlight important information

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Decent clash solvable in a minute or two

Binary output issue
* According to the contribution guidelines, binary outputs should be avoided for clashes. That's exactly the issue with your clash, as it allows only two possible answers (either "YES" or "NO"). Please modify the output requirements to allow for more than two possible answers.

Thanks.
Thank you so much for your comment, I have changed the problem a little bit to allow for three possible answers instead of two.
It seems that the contribution was sabotaged by somebody.
Thank you for updating my version, it seems clearer now :]
